labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Remove tool specification from RFC
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: RFC4053 goes overly into details about the tooling which makes it hard to adjust the tool. Therefore these parts should be removed. This is mainly section 2.2, some parts of 3 and the appendix. Instead I proposed to put some high-level tooling requirements into the appendix, e.g. like it must be possible to upload attachments...

issues.title: IETF is not obligated to reply
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: The RFC says that the IETF is not obligated to reply, except there is an official liaison relationship. I think we are never obligated to reply; the relationship doesn't change that. however if we have a liaison manager, the liaison manager is expected to handle the LS in some way and e.g. communicate back if no reply will be sent.

issues.title: Respond contact and technical contact are unclear
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: Propose is to only have the "from" contact. Currently the tooling also has CC. Do we need that? might be useful because it should map to email?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: PR #11 merged

issues.title: What are the requirements on recording LS?
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: Currently the RFC says: "A liaison statement is a temporary document". however, it is probably important to keep a record and we might want to revise this section

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Should we understand temporary document as living document? should we understand record as permanent record? I am not 100% percent sure we will see liaison statement as permanent record, just like personal email I maintain, I might delete some of emails at some time point or quarterly.
Maybe we should just use one single analogy,i.e., email, since temporary document as another analogy introducing confusing.
Or we simply change it as living document.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: we merged #19 which removed this section on "Lifecycle" and adds a section on recording instead. However, we still leave this issue open for now to double-check if there is more we need to say.

issues.title: "Approval and Transmission of Liaison Statements" is described in RFC4052
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: Should we move this whole section from RFC4052 into this document instead? The requirements in specified in that section in RFC4052 and not specific to cases where we have a liaison manager and therefore would fit better into this document.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Further the text needs to be updated as we discussed with the IESG that all (IETF) LS should have AD approval.

issues.title: Remove Purpose "For Comment"
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: This type of purpose is usually not used. I only checked a small sample set and didn't find a single usage. But we could also analyse the whole set of LSs and see if or how often this is actually used. Usually if comments are expected in a certain time frame "for action" is used; if a response is optional then "for comment" is used. The two cases (plus the "in response" purpose) seem sufficient.

issues.title: Maybe re-add a "Send reply to" field
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: If we want to ensure that in future all LSs are send either _through_ the liaison managers or liaison coordinators, maybe we should re-add a field "send reply to" which either contains the liaison manager alias, e.g. 3gpp-liaison@ietf.org, if applicable or liaison-coordination@iab.org

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Actually I think we need a "From-Liaison-Contact" and a "To-Liaison-Contact". The "From-Liaison-Contact" is the "Sent Reply To" information. However, if the expectation is that a LS is only send to this address when replying, we should also expose this when sending a reply in the "To-Liaison-Contact".

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Also this touches a bit more on tooling but it still be good to be clear here I think.

Whenever we upload a LS, no matter if incoming or outgoing, into the datatacker an email should go out to all contacts belong to the IETF (either "From Contacts" or "To Contacts" depending if outgoing or incoming) to acknowledge that the LS was recorded.

However, for outgoing LSs sent from the IETF, sometimes LS should only be send to a liaison contact email address. This could be covered by adding a "To-Liaison-Contact". If that contact is present/known, the statement will be only directly sent to this address. If not, it will be sent to all address in the "To-Contacts".

Question is should we also do something similar for incoming LSs sent by another org. Usually there is one person that has send out the LS to someone in the IETF and that person in the IETF uploads the LS to the datatracker. Sometimes there might be others from the same org in cc of that original mail. And sometimes there are more people listed in the LS itself (like in an attached word doc or PDF). I guess somehow we should at least send out a confirmation to everybody who was cc'ed in the initial mail when creating the datatracker record. Again we could use the "From-Liaison-Contact" for this. However, using this field would than also mean that a reply would only be set to this set of people as well. But I think that seems actually right to me.

So in summary, if a LS get recorded a confirmation mail is sent to all email address belong to the IETF-side as well as the "From/to-Liaison-Contact" if present. If not present, then the mail is also send to all address in the "From/To Contacts".

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Here are some examples of metadata information from LS that we receive from the orgs:

issues.title: Address liaison statements with deadlines for action
issues.author: sureshkrishnan
issues.body: There should be some text needed to address LSs that arrive with some requested action and deadlines. Potentially also document need for notifications/reminders as well as an escalation chain.

comments.author: billwuqin
comments.body:
Also relate to #30 , Here are related text description as follows:

Section 2.2 Purpose
Liaison statements that request action indicate a deadline when the action is required. If the receiving body cannot accomplish the request within the stated period, courtesy calls for a response offering a more doable deadline or an alternative course of action.

Section 3 Responsibilities when Receiving a Liaison Statement
The urgency of a liaison statement is usually reflected in its deadline. A liaison statement for informational purposes has no deadline; in such a case, a courteous "thank you" liaison statement may be sent to inform the sender that the liaison statement was received. A liaison statement specifying a deadline, however, gives the receiver a finite opportunity to influence the activity of another body; if it fails to react in a timely fashion, it may miss the opportunity.

6. Responding to Incoming Liaison Statements
Any incoming liaison statement that indicates that it is for "Action" requires a response by the deadline. It is the responsibility of the (co)chair(s) of the addressed group to ensure that a response is generated by the deadline if a respone is intended.

Section 6.3 Responding to Request for Action
For tasks that require a great deal of time, it may be necessary that several liaison statements be sent back to the originating organization to report the status of the work and the anticipated completion time. The first of these liaison statements should be generated by the deadline indicated in the incoming liaison statement.

issues.title: double-check list from appendix
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
This is from the old appendix that is now removed from the doc. We might want to check if we still want to discuss any of these feature in the new version of the doc.

> This list of feature was indicated as Phase II in RFC4053 but have
>    never been implemented. Therefore this list is kept for now as a
>    record of high-level intended features of the future liaison statement
>    tracking system:
> 
>    o  Designating an assignee; the assignee is initially a person
>       associated with the body (IAB, IESG, Area, WG, etc.) to which the
>       liaison statement is addressed, but may subsequently be changed by
>       an IETF participant.
> 
>    o  Indicating the status of the liaison statement (e.g., actions
>       required, actions taken, etc.  Specific options TBD).
> 
>    o  Sending ticklers to the assignee when action is required (with
>       copies to whomever is appropriate).
> 
>    o  Changing the status of the liaison statement, the deadline, or
>       other attributes.
> 
>    o  Reassigning responsibility.
> 
>    o  Closing the liaison statement.

issues.title: add changes-from-4053 section and update acknowledgements
issues.author: mirjak

issues.title: Mentions of ASCII should be UTF-8 - "plain text" could be defined once and reused.
issues.author: rjsparks
issues.body: The document mentions "ASCII text" in section 2.3 - I think it should say UTF-8 text instead. I suggest making it clear early that "plain text" means a UTF-8 encoded text/plain document and using that phrase consistently in the rest of the document.

issues.title: Section 2.3 still speaks in terms of web forms and fields
issues.author: rjsparks
issues.body: One goal of the update is to abstract away tooling details. Wording could be adjusted to avoid "forms" and "fields".

issues.title: Should it be explicit that liaison statement documents to/from the IETF/IAB are expected to be in English?
issues.author: rjsparks
issues.body: Should it be explicit that liaison statement documents to/from the IETF/IAB are expected to be in English?

issues.title: Editorial review of Section 5 (Sending LSs) and Section 6 (Responding)
issues.author: mirjak

issues.title: Also note in this doc that LSs have no "special standing"
issues.author: mirjak

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Note that no "special standing" includes that there is no obligation to reply and no reply does not imply endorsement. Sending a contribution or request in a LS is not different than sending an informal email to the wg mailing or respective person/role. Depending on the process of the SDO that has sent the LS, the statement might reflect some level of consensus, however, that doesn't change the weight compared to any contribution but any individual. Also note that LS sent by any IETF group do not automatically imply group or IETF level consensus (effectively only RFCs reflect IETF consensus).

issues.title: Do we care how other SDOs or other party handle liaison statement from IETF
issues.author: billwuqin
issues.body:
RFC4053bis said:
"
Receive of a liaison statement does not automatically impose an obligation of sending a response by the other party. The decision to send a response depends on the content and kind of request. 
"
I am wondering who will be "the other party"? should it be limited to other SDOs? should it also include IETF? If the motivation of the first sentence in the above quoted text is aiming at generic, e..g,
"Receiving of a liaison statement from one party does not automatically impose an obligation of sending a response by the other party", I am wondering whether RFC4053bis can stipulate on how other SDOs handle liaison statement to and from IETF?
If the answer is no, I think we should make the above text clear with the following change:

Receiving of a liaison statement from other SDOs does not automatically impose an obligation of sending a response by the IETF.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: This is keep generic because it is also true that just because we send an LS to some other SDO that's doesn't automatically mean that we will receive a reply. However, we could be more explicit about this but maybe it better to keep it generic in the intro and then be more explicit in the later sections.

issues.title: Clarify consensus when sending LSs from an IETF group
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
Based on a first call for community feedback we received some comments, all regarding the consensus implied when sending a LS from an IETF group.

Eliot Lear wrote:

> A couple of things that have come up from time to time, for the IAB to consider:
>
>    What does it mean for an area to send a liaison that would state a position of that area (e.g., require rough consensus)?  IMHO, areas should not send liaisons.
>    Can the IESG send a liaison that represents its view and not that of the IETF?  And if so, what is the distinction?
>
>These are somewhat pointy headed distinctions, but again from time to time they have come up.

And further:

>  I think the high order bit here, and it really should be normative in the document, is that when any group is speaking (IAB/IESG/area/wg), especially when stating a position, that position must be properly represented as to what form of consensus it has, and whether it is a position of the IETF.  That latter part is important because the peer organizations may not understand our organization.

S. Moonesamy wrote:

>There is the following sentence in rfc4052bis-00:
>
> 'However, if these communications aim to "represent the IETF", they must
>  have consensus, e.g. by being based on an RFC or some other formal statement
>  by a group within the IETF.'
>
>Does that mean that statements discussed and agreed upon within, for example, a working group would be viewed as the position of the IETF Community?

And further (after Suresh replied with an exampled):

> The designation of the sender is clearly visible in the above example.  However, the external party may assume that the statement represents the views of the IETF Community.  My mild suggestion is for your colleagues and you to consider that.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body:
Generally, most of the text about sending statements and approval has been taken so far without much modification from 4053/4052 and we will definitely work on those parts for the next revision (also with the intent to maybe say those things but using less words).

On the question of IESG vs. IETF we actually have a tooling issue/discussion open for that:
https://github.com/ietf-tools/liaison-tooling-2025a/discussions/5

What I’ve seen in the tracker is that both fields have been used interchangeably, so I think it would be better to only have one. I think we do need the ability to send statements from the IETF because that’s what other organizations might expect while IESG might not mean anything to them. But as you say it is of cause important to be clear in the statement what that means and what level of consensus a statement has.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: removing this appendix now but I opened issue #16 instead to double-check later!

pulls.title: Change lifecycle section to recording LSs
pulls.author: mirjak
pulls.body: this removes the original text and mainly moves some later text up.

comments.body:
```suggestion
The IETF will record any received liaison statement and make it publicly available.
For received liaison statement with a
```

```suggestion
them after the fact. This approach is possible e.g. if a certain form
of submission other than email is required by the
```

```suggestion
For the IETF, a liaison statement is a message that was sent or received
(usually an email or some kind of formal letter)
that is recorded in our liaison management tool,
i.e. the value of sending a liaison statement for an organization compared to a mail,
```

pulls.title: header: add suresh as author and obsolete tag
pulls.author: mirjak

pulls.title: section 3.2.1.1 existed in RFC4053 has been moved to section 5.2
pulls.author: billwuqin

comments.body:
I don't think add this is here is the right place to add it.
```suggestion
   working groups, but usually all groups are from the same organization.
```

We should remove the indention everywhere. That's just leftover from the copy-paste of the original RFC. In particularly in list indention has a meaning in markdown.
```suggestion
- In the case of overlapping or related work in another
     organization, another organization may request that the IETF align
     its work with that of the other organization.
- A request could be made for IETF to undertake a new work item.
- A request could be made for IETF to stop a work item (presumably
     because it overlaps or conflicts with other work in the
     originating organization).
```

pulls.title: fix: remove a form/tool specific sentence.
pulls.author: rjsparks

comments.body:
```suggestion
these metadata should be extracted. The content of a statement is recorded as plain text body 
and/or by attaching a received document.
```
Not fully sure we need this, but it might still be useful to say somehow that the body of an attachment does not need to be extracted and converted into plain text...?
@rjsparks does this proposed sentence work or do you think that still has to tight tooling implications?

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Please note that this PR does not address issue #31. This PR only clarifies what the absent of a replies implies but does not clarify that the input provided by a received LS from another SDO has not special handling in the IETF process, e.g. it is not treated different by the process than any input provided by an individual on e.g. a mailing list.

```suggestion
   "Action" expects a response by the deadline.
```

```suggestion
   If no response to an incoming liaison statement is provided, this
   does not imply agreement or consensus on the topic raised to
   the IETF. IETF positions require community rough consensus 
   via processes managed by the Internet Engineering Steering Group (IESG).
```
This is already in the intro. Not sure we need to repeat the exact same sentence here.

pulls.title: Clarify whether  we care how other SDOs or other party handle liaison…
pulls.author: billwuqin

pulls.title: Editorial changes to section 5 and section 6
pulls.author: billwuqin

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Thanks for the editorial proposal. However, this PR does not address issue #30, as the intention is to review and adapt the content appropriately. I think/hope the text can be strongly simplified.
This change is not correct. The sentence takes about activities in the IETF wg

I think WG or even IETF LC is too late. I think this sentence meant to say it better to request input much earlier that this. But maybe we can just remove this sentence because that should be clear or it actually for the chairs to decided when is the right time for input (usually early in the process but when the solution is relatively stable).

pulls.title: Address liaison statements with deadlines for action
pulls.author: billwuqin

comments.body:
Not sure we can put this like this because that's again a tooling requirement that we decided to remove from this document.

@sureshkrishnan what did you have on your mind for this?
